accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 717-719, 722-723, 840 (audiovisual materials): Restricted Fragile Material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Boxes 725-732 (electronic files): Restricted Fragile Material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Rebecca Miller on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2014, and gift of Rebecca Miller, 2018.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: The collection consists of the photographic archive and related papers of Inge Morath that document her work as a photographer, chiefly with Magnum Photos, from the early 1950s through her death.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into seven series: I. Photographs, 1896-2001. II. Papers, 1858-2012. III. Photographs and papers from the Morath-Miller home, 1940-2005. IV. Audiovisual Material, 1960-2004. V. Electronic Files, 1994-2005. VI. Artifacts, 1954-2000. VII. December 2018 Acquisition, circa 1970. VIII. April 2018 Acquisition, 1910-2003.

bioghist.head: Inge Morath (1923-2002)
bioghist.p:
Inge Morath was born in Graz, Austria, in 1923. After studying languages in Berlin, she became a translator, then a journalist and the Austrian editor for Heute, an Information Service Branch publication based in Munich. All her life, Morath would remain a prolific diarist and letter-writer.
A friend of photographer Ernst Haas, she wrote articles to accompany his photographs and was invited by Robert Capa and Haas to Paris to join the newly founded Magnum agency as an editor and researcher. She began photographing in London in 1951, and joined Magnum Photos as a photographer in 1953. While working on her own first assignments, Morath also assisted Henri Cartier-Bresson during 1953-54, becoming a full member in 1955.
In the following years, Morath traveled extensively in Europe, North Africa and the Middle East. Her special interest in the arts found expression in photographic essays published by a number of leading magazines. After her marriage to playwright Arthur Miller in 1962, Morath settled in New York and Connecticut. She first visited the USSR in 1965. In 1972 she studied Mandarin and obtained a visa to China, making the first of many trips to the country in 1978.
Much of Morath's most important work consists of portraits, but of passers-by as well as celebrities. She was also adept at photographing places: her pictures of Boris Pasternak's home, Pushkin's library, Chekhov's house, Mao Zedong's bedroom, artists' studios and cemetery memorials are permeated with the spirit of invisible people still present. Inge Morath died in New York City on 30 January 2002.
For more detail about Morath's life and career, consult the brief biography compiled by the Inge Morath Foundation in Box 1, Folder 1 of the collection

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Inge Morath Photographs and Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, library staff supplied folder titles during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

Before its sale to the Library, the Inge Morath Foundation housed and administered the bulk of the collection at its administrative office in New York City. A small portion of the collection came from the Miller-Morath residence in Roxbury, Connecticut.
Boxes 720 and 721 are unused. Original videocassettes are now housed in box 719. Restricted fragile material.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Black-and-white 35-millimeter negatives created by Inge Morath are held by Magnum Photos in New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographic material in the collection includes contact sheets, color slides, and photographic prints.

Morath's documentary photographs depict people and events in a wide range of countries, including Austria, China, England, France, Germany, India, Italy, Romania, Russia, Spain, and Tunisia, as well as throughout Mexico and the United States.

The collection includes portrait studies of public figures, including Yul Brynner, Alexander Calder, Alberto Giacometti, Dustin Hoffman, Henry Moore, Ana√Øs Nin, Pablo Picasso, Andrei Voznesensky, and Yevgeny Yevtushenko. It also includes projects with her longtime collaborator, artist Saul Steinberg.

Papers in the collection include story lists, captions, notebooks, general files, and publicity related chiefly to her photography. The collection also includes audiovisual material, electronic files, and artifacts.
A group of printed material accompanies the collection and consists of an incomplete set of her monographs, as well as works related to travel, languages, and other subjects.
The collection also chronicles Morath's personal life, including her marriage and family with playwright Arthur Miller, and provides ancillary documentation of his work.
In this guide to the collection, library staff chiefly retained Morath's titles and spellings, while contact sheets include authorized forms of names derived from her story lists.

Chronological arrangements within the collection reflect the image creation date, not the date the photograph was printed. Notes throughout the collection include Morath's "story numbers," when easily discerned by library staff.
Series I, Photographs, includes the bulk of photographic material created by Morath and her personal and family photographs, as well as photographs she collected by other photographers.
Series II, Papers, consists of papers that document the life and work of Morath, including story captions, notebooks, correspondence, clippings, financial records, and awards.

Series III, Photographs and Papers from the Morath-Miller Home, consists of material in the home of Morath and Arthur Miller in Roxbury, Connecticut, immediately before the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library acquired the material in 2014. It includes personal and family photographs, correspondence, writings and travel notebooks, address books, visiting cards, exhibition catalogs, publicity material, art, and ephemera.
Series IV, Audio Visual Material, consists of sound recordings, videocassettes, and films by or about Morath, and includes interviews with her and documentation of her exhibitions.

Series V, Electronic Files, chiefly consists of the electronic files created by Morath, as well as by the Inge Morath Foundation, including image files and backup files, as well as operating system and utility program files used by her.

Series VI, Objects, consists of the items Morath used as a photographer, including a camera, film canisters, and rubber ink stamps used to mark her prints, as well as other personal effects, including scarves and a suitcase.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Inge Morath Photographs and Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Yale University. Ms. Rebecca Miller, her heirs and assigns retain all commercial rights in photographs and writings by Morath. Literary rights, including copyright, of others belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.
The Beinecke Rare Book & Manuscript Library has the limited right to authorize scholars to reproduce up to five of Ms. Morath's images in a scholarly publication.
Any exhibition or reproduction of contact sheets or work prints by Ms. Morath requires their identification as contact sheets or work prints.
The Beinecke Rare Book & Manuscript Library will not reproduce for any purpose photographs or images identified as "Family Photographs" in boxes 509-539, 612, and 701-703.
Photographs by Ms. Morath from the "Mask series" of photographs share copyright with the Saul Steinberg Foundation, and any use thereof requires the approval of the Saul Steinberg Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series documents the photographic work of Morath, as well as photographic material she collected by other photographers.

Morath and other Magnum Photos photographers assigned chronological "story numbers" to their projects. These numbers consist of digits for the year of image creation, followed by a sequential number for the story (assignment, job, or project) within the given year, and then often by numbers that identify the roll and exposure frame. Most of the photographic material in the collection have "story numbers" inscribed on their versos, housings, or mounts.

Related material in Series I, Papers, includes typescript story lists that document the "story numbers" and identify the general subjects, while captions provide group and item-level descriptions of images.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into five subseries: Contact Sheets, Photographic Prints, Color Transparencies, Personal and Family Photographs, and Collected Photographs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized under four headings: Personal Set, Magnum Photos Paris Set, Duplicate Set, and Reference Print Files.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Associated materials: Information about individual "story numbers" can be found in Series II. Papers, Story Lists subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of the contact sheets (usually 8 by 10 inches) of 35-millimeter black-and-white negatives created by Morath that represent the bulk of her black-and-white photographic work and document more than 7,700 rolls of film and 240,000 images.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Associated materials: Information about individual images can be found in Series II. Papers, Captions subseries.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged sequentially by "story number."

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Headings in the Personal Set of Contact Sheets derive from Story Lists filed in the Papers Series. The headings provide general subject access to contact sheets, as well as the "story numbers" scheme for 775 projects and context for identifying photographic material created by Morath throughout the collection. Additionally, the headings document the number of rolls or negatives created when recorded in the Story Lists, as well as any lacking rolls. Not all headings have extant contact sheets. The Story Lists do not include information for stories created after 1991.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This material consists of Morath's personal set of contact sheets.
Many of the contact sheets have inscriptions by Morath on versos, as well as inscriptions on rectos that distinguish individual frames or delineate cropping instructions.
Some contact sheet "story numbers" may overlap between two or more separate binders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographic prints consist of more than 21,000 items, including vintage prints, exhibition/modern prints, and estate quality prints, as well as work prints, copy prints, personal photographs, and photographs by others.
Morath did not print her own photographs. She relied on Magnum Photos and other printers to make the prints under her direction.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized under nine headings: Vintage Prints, Work Prints, Exhibition/Modern Prints, Estate Prints, Subject Reference Prints, Copy Prints, Mixed Prints, Oversize Prints, and Framed Prints.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged sequentially by story number followed by prints with no identified story number.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Inge Morath Foundation arranged this material before acquisition of the collection by the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Vintage prints (approximately 5850), chiefly measuring 8 by 10 inches, made directly from the original negatives soon after their capture, usually on fiber paper. These prints usually have inscriptions by Morath and Magnum Photos staff, including captions, notes, crop marks, numbers, and ink stamps. Most of the early prints bear the photographer's name and/or copyright stamp, a title or other captioning, and the story number.

Morath consigned a group of these prints to the Howard Greenberg Gallery in New York City for exhibition and sale around 1995, and she signed the prints at the request of the gallery for marketing purposes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Work prints (over 6,700) represent enlargements used by Morath for editorial purposes, such as planning monographs and exhibitions. The primarily fiber paper prints measure 8 by 10 inches and 11 by 14 inches made after 1966. Many have comments and notes by Morath on versos and a few bear her signature. The material also includes some color prints.
Notes in the guide to this group of material include represented story numbers when easily discerned by library staff.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Inge Morath Foundation arranged this material before acquisition of the collection by the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Exhibition/Modern prints (approximately 1480), also known as Lifetime prints, represent archival quality photographic prints on fiber paper primarily 11 by 14 inches with a small group of 16 by 20 inches made by fine art printers under Morath's direction for exhibition and sale in galleries from circa 1985 until her death.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Inge Morath Foundation arranged this material before acquisition of the collection by the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Estate prints (approximately 100) are high-quality prints made after Morath's death in 2002. These posthumously created prints include images that Morath did not print during her lifetime.
It also includes 53 digital ink jet prints, 11 by 14 inches, of color photographs by Morath.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Project files represent enlargements probably used by Morath for editorial purposes, such as planning monographs and exhibitions. The primarily fiber paper prints measure 5 by 7 inches and 8 by 10 inches, with occasional prints measuring 11 by 14 inches. Many have notes by Morath on versos.
During initial processing, library staff rehoused the following subject groups: China, Cuba, Connecticut, and New York City, as well as a portion of the Portraits.
Notes in the guide for this group of material include represented story numbers when easily discerned by library staff.

scopecontent.p: This series chiefly includes 35-millimeter color slides (approximately 46,000) that document Morath's color photography during the first two decades of her career and complement her black-and-white images of the same period. It also includes examples of color transparencies and occasional color and black-and-white negatives with variant dimensions including 2 by 2 inches, 4 by 5 inches, and 8 by 10 inches.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II is organized into seven subseries: Story Lists, Captions, Notebooks, General Files, Publicity, Project Files, and Awards.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of papers that document the life and work of Inge Morath. It includes story captions, notebooks, correspondence, clippings, financial records, and awards.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Story Lists describe the subjects of 775 of Morath's photographic projects arranged chronologically. They provide context for identifying photographic material created by her throughout the collection. Additionally, the Story Lists often document the number of rolls or negatives created for a project, as well as any lacking rolls. The Story Lists do not have information for stories created after 1991.

did.unittitle: Rolodex index to the Story List

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized alphabetically by country

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of the captions created by Morath that identify and describe individual images related to story numbers. The captions document her travel, projects, assignments, and subjects of interest. Depending on the story, the captions vary from brief to in-depth descriptions.

Morath and other Magnum Photos photographers assigned chronological story numbers to their projects. These numbers consist of digits for the year of image creation, followed by a sequential number for the story (assignment, job, or project) within the given year, and then often by numbers that identify the roll and exposure frame. The captions for individual story numbers include descriptions from roll to roll and often from exposure frame to frame.
The caption files for discrete story numbers may also contain related correspondence, essays, lists, notes, clippings, brochures, maps, and ephemera.

The sets of captions include duplicates and photocopies. Story lists and indices often accompany captions and provide multiple story numbers for a specific year, which document story numbers Morath used for a single project.
Notes in the guide for this group of material include descriptive inscriptions accompanying the captions.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized under two headings: Personal Set and Magnum New York Set.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Inge Morath Foundation arranged this material before acquisition of the collection by the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series chiefly consists of the electronic files created by Morath. The electronic files consist of image files and backup files, as well as operating system and utility program files used by Morath. The series also includes Morath's computer and an external disk drive unit.
The Inge Morath Foundation created some of the electronic files in this series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series VI is organized into two subseries: Photography Related and Personal Effects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of the items Morath used as a photographer, including a camera, film canisters, and rubber ink stamps used to mark her prints, as well as other personal effects, including scarves and a suitcase.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Morath used the rubber stamps to mark her photographic prints

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Printed material is chiefly organized into two groups: Travel, Language and Ephemera and General Books. It also includes Material Found in Books and The Last Journey portfolio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed material consists of books, periodicals, and other published material by or about Morath and her work, as well as travel and language books used by her.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This group of printed material consists of Morath's travel guides, language books, maps and ephemera.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Russia, a handbook, Costa da morte, Dehio wien, and Walhalla.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This group of material consists of notes, maps, postcards, book inserts, brochures, and other printed items found in or filed with books.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Last Journey is a limited edition portfolio created by Branko Lenart that consists of sixteen photographs of Morath and in remembrance of her. A letter to Arthur Miller from Branko Lenart accompanied the portfolio and describes its creation. This portfolio is number two of ten

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Books, periodicals, and other printed material about Morath and her work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This addition consists of two artworks by Olga Carlisle, given to Inge Morath by the artist.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: This painting previously hung in Inge Morath and Arthur Miller's apartment in New York City.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This drawing previously hung in Inge Morath and Arthur Miller's barn at their home in Roxbury, Connecticut.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains photographs, correspondence, writings, light meters and other camera equipment, personal and family papers, posters, artwork, and audiovisual material by or relating to Inge Morath. Among the correspondents are Henri Cartier-Bresson and Ernst Haas, as well as Morath's parents Mathilde and Edgar Morath, brother Werner Morath, and husband Arthur Miller.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five subseries: Photographs and Artwork, Writings, Correspondence and Other Papers, Objects, and Audiovisual Material.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Gift of Rebecca Miller, 2018.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains photographs by Inge Morath of various places, people, and objects, and photographs and artwork by others, including J. F√≠n, Martine Franck, Pablo Neruda, and Eva Xiao.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized under two subheadings: Photographs by Morath, and Collected Photographs and Artwork. Materials in the first subheading are generally grouped by format and country, but are otherwise not further organized. Materials in the second subheading are arranged alphabetically by folder title, with unidentified items filed at the end of the sequence.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Associated materials: Photographs and artwork can also be found in Writings and Correspondence and Other Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This group of material contains mounted black and white photographs that were displayed in Morath's barn in Roxbury. Included are images from France, Russia, Spain, Tunisia, and the United States, and portraits of authors, artists, and actors such as Alexander Calder, Jean Cocteau, Norman Mailer, Jayne Mansfield, Mary McCarthy, and Pablo Picasso. Notes accompanying the material represent story numbers when easily discerned by library staff.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains diaries, notebooks, and other writings related to Morath's life in Germany and Austria during and immediately following World War II; photography and professional projects; travel to Asia, Europe, Russia, South Africa, and South America; and Mandarin language studies. Included are typescript and autograph manuscript essays, poems, notes on novel and short story ideas, and various memoranda. Correspondence, photographs, clippings, and ephemera are frequently enclosed with writings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Telegrams related to Morath's marriage and brother Werner missing in action in World War II, letters from family, Irish artist Louis Le Brocquy, and others, notes, photographs, address lists, and ephemera.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of personal and family correspondence and papers. Included are letters and postcards to Inge Morath from Dominique Aubier, Henri-Cartier Bresson, Alec Guinness, Ernst Haas, Pablo Neruda, and Josef Schwarzenberg; correspondence between Morath and her mother Mathilde, known as "Titti," father Edgar, and brother Werner, as well as a few letters to Werner from Arthur Miller; family histories and photographs; and clippings. Personal papers of Morath contain early school work and correspondence, photographs, travel documents, a few notebooks, certificates, and ephemera. Also included are posters for exhibitions and other projects featuring Morath's photography.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized under four subheadings: General Correspondence, Family Correspondence and Papers, Personal Papers, and Posters. Within the first three subheadings, materials are arranged alphabetically by correspondent or folder title, with unidentified materials filed at the end of the sequence. Materials in the last subheading are arranged chronologically.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Associated materials: Correspondence can also be found in Photographs and Artwork and Writings.
